How to Solve Internet and Infrastructure Inequalities

Actionable solutions to bridge the digital divide in rural Canada.

The Role of Government Initiatives

The CRTC (Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission) is actively improving connectivity in rural Canada through the Broadband Fund.

  • Since 2019, the fund has connected over 270 communities with high-speed internet and cellphone services.
  • Essential institutions like schools, healthcare centers, and community hubs are prioritized for upgrades.
  • Recent efforts include bringing fiber internet to 16 rural communities in Manitoba.

Source: CRTC - Canada.ca

Harnessing Data Centers in Rural Communities

Rural areas are increasingly attractive for data centers due to:

  • Colder climates reducing cooling costs.
  • Affordable land making large-scale operations viable.
  • Economic benefits such as job creation and local investments.

For example, small towns in the U.S. like those in Virginia and Iowa are leveraging these advantages to host facilities for tech giants, creating a model Canada can follow.

Sources: Harrington, 2024, Starner, 2024

Legislative Support for Faster Deployment

Ontario's government is removing bureaucratic barriers to speed up infrastructure projects:

  • Property laws allow faster land acquisition for internet towers with fair compensation to owners.
  • Interactive maps showcase ongoing and planned high-speed projects in areas like First Nations communities and Highway 11-17 corridors.

Source: Ontario Connects - Ontario.ca

Investing in Cloud and Data Security

Companies like IBM are leading the way with cloud innovations:

  • New Cloud Multizone Regions prioritize data sovereignty, security, and performance.
  • These technologies cater to Canada's regulated industries and rural connectivity needs.

Source: IBM Canada Newsroom, 2024
